results.title: ‘Passing’ Review: Black Skin, White Masks
results.abstract: Rebecca Hall’s piercing drama stars Tessa Thompson and Ruth Negga as old friends navigating the color line in 1920s New York.

multimedia.caption: Ruth Negga, left, as Clare and Tessa Thompson as Irene in “Passing.”

results.title: ‘Belfast’ Review: A Boy’s Life
results.abstract: In this charming memoir, Kenneth Branagh recalls his childhood in Northern Ireland through a rose-tinted lens.

multimedia.caption: Front row from left, Caitriona Balfe, Jamie Dornan, Judi Dench, Jude Hill and Lewis McAskie in “Belfast.”

results.title: Lady Gaga and Ridley Scott on ‘House of Gucci’: When Beauty Turns Ugly
results.abstract: To play a fashionista willing to kill in the director’s fact-based drama, his star plunged deeply into character. “How could I possibly turn it off?” she said.

multimedia.caption: Ridley Scott and Lady Gaga in Los Angeles before “House of Gucci” premiered in London.
multimedia.copyright: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

results.title: The Glory of Nina Mae McKinney, an Early Black Star in White Hollywood
results.abstract: With the 1929 “Hallelujah!,” the actress shot to stardom. Hollywood made sure she didn’t stay there, as a new Film Forum series shows.

multimedia.caption: Nina Mae McKinney in a scene from “Hallelujah!”

results.title: ‘Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone’ at 20: The Film That Started It All
results.abstract: Two decades after the film’s release, Daniel Radcliffe and the director, Chris Columbus, take us inside four key scenes.
des_facet: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Daniel Radcliffe, center, in the first Harry Potter film, with, from left, Leilah Sutherland, James Phelps, Sean Biggerstaff and Oliver Phelps.

results.title: Watch Kristen Stewart Embody Princess Diana in ‘Spencer’
results.abstract: The director Pablo Larraín narrates a sequence from his film.

results.title: ‘Julia’ Review: She Changed Your Life and Your Utensil Drawer
results.abstract: An invigorating new documentary looks back on Julia Child and her influence on how Americans cook and eat.

multimedia.caption: Julia Child and a fridge friend in an archival image as seen in the documentary, “Julia,” directed by Julie Cohen and Betsy West.
multimedia.copyright: Paul Child/Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University/Sony Pictures Classics

results.title: ‘Always Jane’ Is Part of a New Generation of Trans Documentaries
results.abstract: For decades, films about transgender people tended to be sensationalistic. A newer crop is more celebratory — and opening doors for its young subjects.
des_facet: Becoming Nicole: The Transformation of an American Family (Book)

multimedia.caption: Jane Noury, the focus of a new docu-series, “Always Jane,” said she believed the director “really wanted to tell a story where a family just shows their love and acceptance of their trans child.”
multimedia.copyright: Tonje Thilesen for The New York Times

results.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include mutants in love and mushrooms out for blood.
des_facet: Horror Noire: A History of Black Horror (Movie)
Nobody Sleeps in the Woods Tonight 2 (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Eric Tabach in “Dashcam.”

results.title: Hollywood crew union narrowly ratifies its contracts with studios.
results.abstract: The margin was perilously narrow, with many International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees members viewing the pact as toothless in terms of preventing long working hours.
org_facet: International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees

multimedia.caption: IATSE members prepared for a strike before negotiators reached tentative agreements with film and television studios.
multimedia.copyright: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times

results.title: The Great High-Fashion Family Film Experiment
results.abstract: The Rodarte designers on creating costumes for the sequel to the animated film “Sing.”

multimedia.caption: A still from “Sing 2,” with costumes designed by Rodarte.

results.title: ‘What Do We See When We Look at the Sky?’ Review: But I Digress
results.abstract: Two strangers become near-lovers in a movie that invites you to think more about the perfectly, simply, ordinary life around them.
des_facet: What Do We See When We Look at the Sky? (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Ani Karseladze in “What Do We See When We Look at the Sky?,” directed by Alexandre Koberidze.

results.title: ‘Cusp’ Review: Teenage Girls, Stuck With Shrugging Off Harm
results.abstract: What starts as a documentary about three Texan high schoolers becomes a look at the normalization of sexual abuse.

multimedia.caption: The documentary “Cusp” focuses on three teenage girls in Texas.

results.title: Jonathan Reynolds, Playwright and Food Columnist, Dies at 79
results.abstract: His plays tended to parody American institutions. His food writing tended to be full of humor.

multimedia.caption: Jonathan Reynolds in 2003 in “Dinner With Demons,” a one-man show in which he cooked a full dinner onstage.

results.title: ‘Night Raiders’ Review: A Future That Resembles the Past
results.abstract: A mother joins a group of vigilantes to help free her daughter from a state-run academy in this feature from Danis Goulet.

multimedia.caption: Elle-Maija Tailfeathers in “Night Raiders.”

results.title: ‘Uppercase Print’ Review: Between the Lines
results.abstract: Radu Jude’s rousing, form-bending new feature rails at the power of propaganda to suffocate people’s freedoms.

multimedia.caption: A scene from Radu Jude’s “Uppercase Print.”

results.title: ‘3212 Un-Redacted’ Review: Trying to Solve a Mission’s Mysteries
results.abstract: The documentary looks into the complex circumstances involving four American soldiers who were killed in an ambush in Niger in 2017.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Col. Mark E. Mitchell in “3212 Un-Redacted.”

results.title: ‘Paper & Glue’ Review: A Sequel of Sorts to ‘Faces Places’
results.abstract: JR, plying his art of making and displaying gigantic portraits, carries on, this time without the inimitable Agnès Varda.

multimedia.caption: An aerial view of the prison at Tehachapi, Calif., with a supersize image of inmates, as seen in “Paper & Glue,” a documentary by the artist JR.

results.title: ‘They Say Nothing Stays the Same’ Review: Crossing a Modern River
results.abstract: Two events disturb the placid surfaces of a boatman’s world: the building of a nearby bridge, and his discovery of a young woman floating in the water.
des_facet: They Say Nothing Stays the Same (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Ririka Kawashima in “They Say Nothing Stays the Same,” about Meiji-era Japan.

results.title: ‘Love Is Love Is Love’ Review: Aging Too Gracefully
results.abstract: The characters in this idle drama, directed by Eleanor Coppola, seem mostly content. That’s the problem.

multimedia.caption: Joanne Whalley plays a woman on a virtual date in “Love Is Love Is Love.”

results.title: ‘Home Sweet Home Alone’ Review: A Winter With Plenty of Falls
results.abstract: Dan Mazer’s film, streaming on Disney+, is a painful spiritual sequel to the 1990 hit.

multimedia.caption: Archie Yates in “Home Sweet Home Alone.”

results.title: ‘Mayor Pete’ Review: Politics Is Local
results.abstract: This film, which follows Pete Buttigieg on his campaign for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, rarely captures him in what looks like an unselfconscious moment.

multimedia.caption: Pete Buttigieg taking a selfie with supporters during his campaign for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination.

results.title: ‘7 Prisoners’ Review: Survival at Any Cost
results.abstract: Alexandre Moratto plunges into the psychological traumas of human trafficking in this gripping Brazilian drama on Netflix.

multimedia.caption: Christian Malheiros in “7 Prisoners.”

results.title: Know How the Beatles Ended? Peter Jackson May Change Your Mind.
results.abstract: The director’s three-part documentary “Get Back” explores the most contested period in the band’s history and reveals there’s still plenty to debate.

multimedia.caption: The Beatles capped a challenging January 1969 with an impromptu lunchtime performance on a London rooftop.

results.title: ‘Red Notice’ Review: When the Stars Don’t Shine
results.abstract: This globe-trotting heist thriller starring Dwayne Johnson, Ryan Reynolds and Gal Gadot is yet another vacant bid at franchise creation.

multimedia.caption: From left, Ryan Reynolds, Dwayne Johnson and Gal Gadot in “Red Notice.”

results.title: ‘Rust’ Crew Member Sues Gun Handlers, Producers and Alec Baldwin
results.abstract: The film’s gaffer accused the production of negligence, and described holding the cinematographer, a longtime friend, as she lay dying after she was struck by a live round fired by Mr. Baldwin.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs, Adam Nagourney and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: The chief lighting technician on the film “Rust” filed a lawsuit charging negligence in the fatal shooting of its cinematographer, Halyna Hutchins.

results.title: ‘Clifford the Big Red Dog’ Review: Fetch Me if You Can
results.abstract: The beloved cartoon dog gets the live-action treatment in this generic canine caper.

multimedia.caption: Darby Camp, left, and Jack Whitehall with the titular canine in “Clifford the Big Red Dog.”

results.title: Billy Crystal to Return to Broadway in ‘Mr. Saturday Night’
results.abstract: The musical, about a comedian’s rise and fall, plans to open at the Nederlander Theater in the spring.

multimedia.caption: Billy Crystal in 2020. His previous Broadway show, “700 Sundays,” was an autobiographical one-man play that opened in 2004.
multimedia.copyright: Vivien Killilea/Getty Images For Palm Springs International Film Festival

results.title: The ‘Rust’ Shooting Spurs a Debate Over Using Guns on Film Sets
results.abstract: Alec Baldwin, who fatally shot a cinematographer with a gun he had been told was safe, has called for productions to hire police officers to monitor gun safety.

multimedia.caption: The fatal shooting on the set of “Rust” in New Mexico last month has prompted a debate about the use of real firearms in film and television productions.

results.title: New Initiative Aims to Change How Movies Portray Muslims
results.abstract: An advocacy group has created a worker database with help from Disney to bring more Muslims into the filmmaking process.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Ali’s Wedding” (2017), which was cited in a report about Muslims in movies as having “the only present-day Muslim lead.”

results.title: Dean Stockwell, Child Actor Turned ‘Quantum Leap’ Star, Dies at 85
results.abstract: He appeared alongside Frank Sinatra and Gene Kelly when he was not yet 10. He later had signature roles in movies like “Married to the Mob” and “Blue Velvet.”

multimedia.caption: Mr. Stockwell as an eccentric criminal in David Lynch’s film “Blue Velvet,” from 1986.

results.title: Joe Pera and the Surprising Pleasures of Gentle Humor
results.abstract: Don’t expect twists in these bits. The standup, who will be at the New York Comedy Festival, has devised a calming aesthetic with rewards of its own.
des_facet: Joe Pera Talks With You (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Joe Pera is the rare comic who will say that he doesn’t mind if you fall asleep listening to him.

results.title: ‘Sooryavanshi’ Review: Cops on a Crusade
results.abstract: The latest in Rohit Shetty’s Bollywood cop franchise is both overstuffed and paper-thin.

multimedia.caption: Akshay Kumar in “Sooryavanshi.”
